content:
While it is possible that the presence of Russian warships in Korean waters may have been seen as a form of intimidation by some, the primary goal of Russia's naval presence in the region was to expand its influence and secure access to warm-water ports on the Pacific coast.

At the time, Russia was seeking to expand its power and influence in East Asia, and had been involved in a number of conflicts and diplomatic disputes in the region. Russia had also been involved in previous conflicts over Korea and had supported Chinese efforts to maintain control over Korea in the First Sino-Japanese War.

The presence of Russian warships in Korean waters was thus part of a broader effort by Russia to establish its presence in the region and secure its strategic and economic interests. While this may have been perceived as a form of intimidation by some, it was primarily driven by Russia's own goals and interests, rather than by any specific intention to intimidate Korea.
